conclusion: Forces on the block while it just begins to slide upward along the plank.
Horizontal force F1 acts to the left on the block.
Vertical force F2 acts upward on the block.
Gravity mg acts downward on the block.
Kinetic-friction force fk acts down the plank, opposite to the block’s upward motion.
Normal force N exerted by the plank acts horizontally toward the block.
Normal force equals the horizontal push, N = F1.
Kinetic friction magnitude is fk = μN = μF1.
Plank receives a horizontal force N = F1 pushing it rightward.
Plank receives a kinetic-friction force fk = μF1 pushing it upward along the wall.
Wall is smooth, so it can only give the plank a horizontal reaction.
Floor can give the plank a vertical reaction but no horizontal friction.
Condition for the plank to start moving upward.
Upward kinetic-friction force fk must exceed plank's weight Mg: fk ≥ Mg.
Condition μF1 ≥ Mg derived from fk ≥ Mg.
Insert the data: μ = 0.20, M = 0.40 kg, g = 10 m/s².
